Fertiliser

Your plant is reliant on the small pot of soil its in, so you'll need to supplement it in order to keep your plant healthy and growing strong.

When

Fertilise your plants during the growing season, and taper off during autumn as your plant will go dormant in winter.

What

Liquid feed is best, I prefer organic seaweed fertilisers for all my plants, though you get specific combinations for vegetative growth, flowers and fruit (increased potassium), orchids & fishbone cactuses, etc.

How

Fertiliser can burn your plant roots, so the trick is to fertilise the day after you water your plant. I don't always do this myself, but it's recommended.

Water

The biggest learning curve for beginners is to remember that watering cannot be scheduled. Sure, you can check on the plant on a schedule, but if the top inch or two of the soil is damp then don't water your plant. It doesn't need it.

When

Plants differ on this. The Calathea ornanta hates getting dried out, but the Hoya Carnosa and Sanseviera require it.

What

I live in a hard water area, and so I use filtered water for many of my plants and distilled water (not mineral/deionised water) for my Calathea ornata and my Dionaea muscipula (Venus flytrap).

How

Generally, water your plants when the top two inches of soil are dry, and water them enough so that it pours out the base of your pot. Sometimes I do this twice so I know the soil has been drenched. This isn't overwatering, as I let the plant dry out between waters.

Exceptions to this rule include: Sanseviera, Succulents, Ceropegia woodii, Dionaea muscipula, Calathea ornata.
